executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency.

The Ink Manufacturing industry produces a range of printing inks and cartridges used by professionals. The industry has come under pressure as traditional forms of printed media have continued their long-term contraction. The transition to digital media has had profound implications for the industry. Demand for all publishing has suffered while print advertising expenditure has contracted, suppressing industry demand. The industry slumped at a CAGR of 5.8% to $4.0 billion over the past five years, including an expected decline of 5.5% in 2024, alone. The pandemic exacerbated poor conditions, encouraging remote workspaces and normalizing online advertising instead of print.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: DIGITAL MEDIA TRENDS RUN INK MANUFACTURERS INTO THE GROUND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: More consumers have turned to the internet and e-readers as replacements for newspapers, magazines and books. As consumers have transitioned to digital media for news and leisure activities, the reach of print advertisements has plummeted.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE E-COMMERCE BOOM CREATES SOME RELIEF
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite digitalization's negative impact on the publishing market, an increase in online shopping has pushed packaging manufacturers to new heights. Packaging manufacturers must purchase more significant quantities of ink, particularly flexographic and gravure inks to meet expanding shipping demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Buyers Transition to Nonimpact, Flexographic and Gravure Inks
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As newspaper, magazine and book publishing industries contract in favor of online alternatives over the outlook period, so too will demand for publishing-related lithographic and offset printing inks.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INK MANUFACTURERS TURN TO ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY PRODUCTS TO STIMULATE GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To combat changing regulations and evolving public opinion, many ink manufacturers have heavily invested into research and development for eco-friendly inks.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DECREASING CRUDE OIL PRICE VOLATILITY STABILIZES PROFIT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Ink manufacturers heavily rely on crude oil inputs. As prices rose following the pandemic, manufacturers were able to charge more, but additional purchasing costs eroded profit.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry manufacture inkjet cartridges and printing and inkjet inks, including lithographic, flexographic, gravure and letterpress inks. These products are sold to commercial printers, newspaper and magazine printers, office supplies wholesalers and screen printers. This industry does not include operators that manufacture writing, drawing and stamping ink or toner cartridges for photocopiers, fax machines and computer printers.
key_trends: Domestic manufacturers face extreme pressure from imports.
Foreign manufacturers leverage low production costs to take customers from domestic producers.
Manufacturers compete to offer the best price, consistency and product line. Major companies can invest freely in new product lines, giving them a competitive advantage over smaller manufacturers.
As businesses and consumers switch to online advertising and reading, the industry will contract. Digital advertising campaigns

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment primarily uses offset and lithographic inks for printing newspapers, books, advertising materials like flyers and direct mail. It has rapidly declined due to consumer shifts away from print media and towards digital platforms.

This segment includes inks made for packaging materials and stationery used by packaging companies. It has grown alongside the rise of e-commerce and shipping. Packagers choose inks based on legibility, durability and production speed for different packaging materials.

products_and_services.product_description: Lithographic and offset inks are used for printing magazines, newspapers, books, catalogs and legal documents. This method is best suited for producing large volumes of prints.

Flexographic inks consist of colorants like pigments, dyes or solvents. They are commonly used for packaging industries like printing on labels, flexible packaging, corrugated packaging, bags and folding cartons. UV-curable flexographic inks are also popular for outdoor signs and advertising.
Nonimpact digital inks are used alongside nonimpact digital printers like inkjet and laser printers. They are sprayed or rolled onto the page instead of being struck by a metal print head.
Gravure inks have low viscosity and are used for high-quality printing where sharp images are preferred, such as food labels, wallpaper, wrapping paper, furniture laminates and greeting cards.
Letterpress printing was once the primary form of printing before offset printing innovations. Letterpress inks maintain a small share through hobbyists, collectors and small publications.
Manufacturers also produce a variety of specialty inks like metallic inks for children's toys or solvent-resistant inks for printed circuit boards.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: An increase in print advertising expenditure reflects the general popularity of print media. As more readers purchase print media for news and entertainment content, magazines can use high readership rates to negotiate higher advertisement rates. Print advertising has faced strong competition from TV and internet advertising, limiting ink sales. Declines in print advertising expenditure hinder the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Low-Cost Producers Dominate the Trade Market
international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic competitors face pressure from low-cost imports, especially from Asian countries like China, Malaysia and Singapore with little wage regulation.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Chinese Imports Slide During Trade Wars
international_trade_points.trade_description: Chinese imports have dropped sharply following the US-China trade war escalation, with Japan and Malaysia overtaking China as top importers.
Canada and Mexico account for over one-third of US ink exports due to the USMCA trade agreement and proximity reducing transportation costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Rising Value of the US Dollar Hinders Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: The rising value of the US dollar has made domestic goods more expensive, leading buyers to source from low-cost foreign suppliers instead.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast holds the largest portion of ink manufacturers due to lax environmental and taxation laws, large population for sourcing inexpensive labor, and proximity to supply chain members in the region like Mexico.

The Great Lakes houses much of the industry's supply chain like dye, pigment and chemical manufacturers. It is also centrally located for selling to clients across the US and facilitates trade with top importer Canada.

Many suppliers like dye and pigment manufacturers are located in the Mid-Atlantic region. Ink manufacturers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania benefit from this proximity to cut transportation costs. New York also has a strong printing industry.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Air pollution control regulations affecting this industry are detailed in Title 1 of the Code of Federal Regulations (Parts 50-99) within the CAA. The emission of hazardous air pollutants (HAPs) is a primary concern due to the gases emitted when toxic chemicals are blended to produce adhesives.

Water pollution regulations for ink manufacturers are detailed in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (Part 447), which details the CWA. Established in 1977, the CWA gives guidelines for the amount of wastewater pollutants generated by regulating direct and indirect discharges.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Established in 1976, the RCRA gives the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) the authority to control all aspects of hazardous waste, including all steps from its creation to its disposal.

Many ink manufacturers are subject to the provisions of Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA). The EPCRA was enacted to enable planning for chemical emergencies and to provide notification in the event of a chemical emergency.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline life cycle stage.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Product differentiation is difficult since companies struggle to compete with low-cost manufacturers. Also, new entrants often can't invest heavily in researching and developing new, cutting-edge products.
Domestic manufacturers face extreme pressure from imports. Foreign manufacturers leverage low production costs to take customers from domestic producers.
Manufacturers compete to offer the best price, consistency and product line.
Major companies can invest freely in new product lines, giving them a competitive advantage over smaller manufacturers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: High international competition has pressured profit, encouraging consolidation. For instance, Flint Group has acquired multiple US ink manufacturers over the past decade to expand its core market segments.
Many large conglomerates are also spinning off unprofitable ink manufacturing businesses. Similarly, small and unprofitable manufacturers have exited or consolidated to stimulate growth.

Each product line requires extensive machinery and investment. Often, companies will need different facilities for different ink types. This means companies typically operate in niche environments; only the most prominent manufacturers will cross through multiple markets.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Ink manufacturers' largest input purchases include dyes, pigments, oils, resins and solvents. Many of these chemicals require crude oil. Oil prices skyrocketed following the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, forcing up purchasing costs significantly.
Crude oil price fluctuations have heavily influenced the industry's profit growth during the current period. As the world price of crude oil skyrocketed, operating costs followed.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Merger and acquisition activity has helped buoy profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Merger and acquisition activity has helped buoy profit over the short term despite the industry's overall decline.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers rely on skilled labor for all aspects of production, especially quality assurance and research and development.
Manufacturers rely on skilled labor for all aspects of production, especially quality assurance and research and development.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Manufacturers rely on crude oil products, like petrochemicals, to make ink. Volatility especially increased following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Russia is a major OPEC+ (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries) member.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturers Supplanted by Online Media Consumption
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Printing industry (IBISWorld report 32311), a major buyer of ink products, is declining as people shift to more accessible online forms of media.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies have had to adapt to changing environmental legislation. Successful brands prioritize research and development for inks involving fewer chemicals and production volatile organic compounds (VOCs).

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Innovation Hinges on Downstream Market Technological Change
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Ink manufacturers often respond to changes in major downstream markets and adapt production to buyers' needs. For example, printer innovations, particularly inkjet and laser printers, have led to major innovation opportunities for nonimpact inks.

FAQs.question: Have any export opportunities presented themselves to your company as the economy gradually reopened?
FAQs.answer: Industry exports have fallen in recent years as US-made inks have become less competitive in the international marketplace.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or does it produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: While some ink manufacturers specialize in one kind of ink, others produce a wide range of ink types.

FAQs.question: How has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Oil is a major input into ink. Therefore, as the price of oil drastically fluctuated over the past five years, input prices changed substantially.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices due to unstable commodity markets?
FAQs.answer: Oil is a primary input in industry goods, and the commodity's price has been volatile in recent years. Normally, this would affect industry sales, but as ink became a less necessary purchase for more consumers, the prices of industry goods also dropped, hurting revenue performance.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your company's customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: While most consumers of ink are repeat purchasers, many downstream customers have cut back on ink orders in recent years as the world has become increasingly digital.

FAQs.question: How does your company support relationships with local buyers? Can it offer incentives to gain more contracts?
FAQs.answer: Strong relationships with downstream users enable manufacturers to tailor inks to specific buyers.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in R&D to meet changing consumer and regulatory preferences?
FAQs.answer: To develop new products, ink manufacturers must conduct research and development (R&D). R&D teams work to develop new ink formulas that offer better color reproduction, drying time, adherence to different materials, durability, and other properties. This could involve experimentation with various pigments, solvents, and other chemicals used in ink production.

FAQs.question: What measures does your company have in place to control costs?
FAQs.answer: Most downstream industries are highly price competitive. By controlling production costs, ink manufacturers can make their products more attractive to downstream users.

FAQs.question: To what degree is your company's revenue reliant on demand from print advertisers? How has it coped as ad spending fell during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: As more readers purchase print media for news and entertainment content, magazines can use high readership rates to negotiate higher advertisement rates.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor changes in the prices of paper input products?
FAQs.answer: As the price of paper increases, the cost of printing rises, which may encourage printed media outlets to shift their focus away from printed distribution and toward digital media.

FAQs.question: How has the depreciation of the US dollar affected your company?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) represents the value of the US dollar relative to foreign currencies. When the TWI is low, US-manufactured ink becomes
